BC-BORDER-PATROL-BOS 
LENGTHY US-CANADA BORDER REPLETE WITH LEAKS 

  
 (i and a coding)   (For use by New York Times News Service clients)  
 By SCOTT ALLEN  
 c.1999 The Boston Globe  
 

   Forest City, Maine, with its winter population of five, is
hardly a hot spot for illegal immigration from Canada. So trusting
are Immigration and Naturalization Service officials that,
normally, only a surveillance camera guards the border crossing
after the federal agent goes home for the day.

   But a lot has changed this week.

   For the first time since the Persian Gulf War in 1991, US border
officials have been put on a heightened state of alert, and they
are particularly concerned about the 798-mile stretch of the border
along New England. Not only is the rural, wooded border lightly
guarded, but it is near the major Canadian cities of Montreal and
Quebec.

   Over the years, smugglers of everything from cigarettes to
illegal aliens have found the New England border an easy target.
But the arrests this week in Vermont of two people amid speculation
they may be involved in terrorism has cast the smuggling issue in a
more sinister light.

   ``I'm concerned about the border out here. I'm wondering if it's
possible for (terrorists) to go across because it is such a remote
area. It would be an easy job at night,'' said Donna Gilman,
postmaster in Brookton, which provides mail to Forest City. ``It
gives me pause.''

   Officials at the Immigration and Naturalization Service say they
have ratcheted up security along the 5,500-mile US-Canadian border
more as a precaution than in response to a specific threat.
Christmas vacations for Border Patrol agents are being cancelled,
and staff increased so that no one works alone and all official
border checkpoints, including tiny Forest City, have 24-hour
staffing.

   ``We want to be on the safe side,'' said Raymond Kelly, director
of the US Customs Service, which manages border checkpoints along
with INS. ``It's prudent. It's not in response to any specific
threat. We just think it's wise to do it.''

   But, with only 107 Border Patrol agents assigned to guard the
entire region, some federal law enforcement officials believe more
are needed to pose a real threat to border jumpers.

   ``If someone wants to carry out an intelligent plan to cross the
border undetected, I'd say the chances of them getting through are
pretty good,'' said Jay McCloskey, the U.S. Attorney for Maine, who
has prosecuted numerous immigration cases during a 20-year-career.

   Sunday's arrest of Bouabide Chamchi, an Algerian, along with
Canadian Lucia Garofalo, at the border crossing in Beecher Falls in
northeastern Vermont came very close to home for some people.
Coupled with the earlier arrest of an Algerian Ahmed Ressam in
Washington on charges of trying to smuggle bomb-making supplies
into the country, it put a threatening new focus on the world's
longest open border.

   ``We know that some of these entry locations may have been
identified by terrorist groups and we've cancelled all annual
leave,'' said Roland Richardson, deputy chief with the US Border
Patrol in Houlton, Maine. ``All of our agents are on the job and
happy to be there given the possibility of entries that could be
coming through here.''

   In truth, the US-Canada border, unlike the US border with
Mexico, was never designed to be leak-proof. Families live on both
sides of the border in communities such as Calais, Maine, and St.
Stephen, New Brunswick, while part of the library in Derby, Vt., is
actually in Canada. For these communities, frequent border
crossings are a way of life.

   ``People might cross the border three times a day coming to the
store, going to visit grandma or whatever,'' said Jean Ouellette,
deputy director of the Immigration and Natural Service regional
office in Portland, Maine, noting these people tend to support
measures making border crossing easier.

   Ouellette estimates that one-third of the 15 million people who
enter New England from Canada each year come through just three
stations, including Calais. Some of the 36 other official border
crossings in the region, such as Pittsburg, N.H., receive fewer
than 100 border crossings a day.

   In addition, for long stretches of the 600-mile Maine border
with Canada, only unguarded logging roads connect the two
countries. In such rural areas, border crossers are either subject
to video surveillance or directed by a sign to check in at the
nearest staffed border crossing.

   Over the years, New England's frontier has sometimes been
targeted by smugglers of both humans and material goods. Slightly
west of New England, the most notorious smuggling route is the
Akwesasne Mohawk Reserve between New York State and Ontario, near
Quebec. Illegal immigrants pay Indian guides to bring them to the
United States side every year, counting on Canadian and American
reluctance to crack down on an Indian reserve.

   However, Marcus Russell at the Immigration and Naturalization
Service in Houlton, Maine, estimates that less than one-tenth of
one percent of the 15 million people who come from Canada into New
England each year are attempting to do something illegal.

   Indeed, Border Patrol agents detained just 3,025 people in the
last fiscal year in New England and eastern New York, a tiny
fraction of those arrested entering the United States from Mexico.
Some say the low numbers reflect the fact that the Border Patrol
has just 107 agents to patrol almost 1,000 miles of border, but
federal officials say sensors and video cameras hidden in the woods
increase the reach of their force.

   Along the border Wednesday, some residents accepted federal
reassurances, noting that many of these border regions are so tight
knit that strangers stand out.

   ``People know everybody here . . . Even if you cross in the
middle of a field here, someone's going to see you and you'll get
caught.'' John Martin of Richford, Vt.

     
(Globe correspondents A. Jay Higgins and Matthew Taylor and Globe
staff reporter Colin Nickerson contributed to this report.)
